Looking at the str2List method: it converts a string like "5 3 8" into a map where key 0 maps to 5, key 1 to 3, key2 to8 etc. But since in the loop, the keys are accessed with i from 0 to n-1, but in Fortran, it's arrays starting at 1. So maybe instead of a map, since in Fortran arrays are straightforward, we can just read them as arrays and just use indices 1 to n. Because the Java code's map is just to get the i-th element by index. First, read n, then allocate v and c arrays of size n.

Wait, but how to read the values?
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Wait, in Fortran, when reading a line of space-separated integers, you can read directly into the array. So step by step. The code outline:

program atcoder_abc125_b
  implicit none
  integer :: n, i, max, profit
  integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: v, c

  read(*,*) n
  allocate(v(n))
  allocate(c(n))

  read(*,*) v
  read(*,*) c

  max = 0
  do i = 1, n
    profit = v(i) - c(i) if (profit > 0) then
      max = max + profit
    end if
  end do

  print*, max

  deallocate(v)
  deallocate(c)

end program atcoder_abc125_b

Wait, but in Fortran, the arrays are read directly from the input line.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: For example, after allocating the v array of size n, the read statement read(*,*) v will read the next line's numbers into the array. program atcoder_abc125_b
  implicit none
  integer :: n, i, max, profit

end program atcoder_abc125_b
